title: Pick order always supreme?
body:
I've seen this a few times:

{{champion:59}}  1: Jungle
{{champion:236}} 2: AD
{{champion:222}} 3: AD
{{champion:103}} 4: Mid
{{champion:53}} 5: Support

{{champion:59}}  and {{champion:222}}  are duo.

{{champion:59}} : I'm picking 3rd picks ADC so we can trade.
{{champion:236}} : *locks in AD*

who has the "right" to go AD?

Usually ends in a dodge or a troll.

replies.body:
Pick order is always supreme *if* you can't talk it out. That's what the generally agreed rule is.

But this situation you describe could not happen. It's just not possible.

Pick order always.

the fact your duo doesn't mean you can have a monopoly on the picks

Answer = player 2

player 1 picked the ADC first, player 2 locked in a 2nd ADC.

player 2 is the %%%%%%ed troll %%%%.

if player 1 picked and ADC champ.. then yes.. that's okay player 1 is in the right
player 2 needs to find another role ( i agree with you there )


**HOWEVER**

trading shouldn't really be mentioned.. player 1 should of just picked, then accepted the fact he may lose jungle role.. thats unfortunate but still fair.

again

just because 2 people Q together doesn't mean they can dictate the game and have a monopoly on the picks

False, communication is key, if players are trading then they should tell the team what they're doing and the team should work things out accordingly, unfortunately in low elo people act like 15 year old kids and argue over everything, you're in for a big surprise when you see the difference between low elo champ select and high elo champ select, this isn't even a problem in high elo, i would suck it up and pick something else.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v7-2OS2kSWM

Perfect example in a Diamond game EUW.

1st pick: Mid. anyone want Reksai? i can first pick
3rd pick: pick me reksai i will trade.
2nd pick: *locks in Fizz* Mid.
Yeah it's really sad in low elo no one utilizes champ select/pick order how it is meant to be used. They all just want their pref position and champ.

In high elo we would communicate and work things out, we would understand who's trading and what they're doing and work things out accordingly, first pick is picking an ADC, third pick is jungle, simple, no need to argue over something so small second pick should just suck it up that they aren't getting the role they want this game and should move onto something else.

Also, he first picked an ADC, you were second pick, if pick order is always supreme then guess what you were in the wrong here not them, this should never have even been an argument.

1 picking 3s champ doesn't give 3 the right but then you need to consider the pick order. If it's 1+2 then enemy picks then 3+4, 1 has the right, a little more complicated if its 1 then enemy picks then 2+3, since they're both picking at the same time. But ultimately 1 did the wrong thing.

1 did the right thing. if they picked a champ/role...regardless of trading. then that role is taken. if #2 takes a 2nd ADC when one is already picked and expects to go that role...THEY are in the wrong.

if 1 picked the jungler and said trading for ADC, then they are in the wrong, but if an ADC is picked...and some %%%% comes and picks a 2nd one expecting the same role, the the %%%% is the problem, not the one who picked it first.
2 had the right to take jungle because of pick order, but still a %%%% move if 3 said he was trading to 1.

overall, 2 is the %%%%. call order is just to determine courtesy. so if the order of calling was different to the order of picking, it was up to the person who called 2nd to offer to change/ask for the spot. still ends with #2 being the %%%% locking in an aDC when one was already picked.

ITS PICK ORDER, not TRADE order. if its PICKED and going to be traded, its STILL PICKED.
